BodyCopy.p:
Don't miss the December issue of Captive Insurance Company Reports (CICR), with a focus on captive governance and setting the foundation for management. This month's issue contains a number of corporate governance perspectives from seasoned captive insurance industry professionals to help you get informed about the issues and opportunities so that you can better serve your captive entity.
Don't Miss this Issue of CICR

ul.li: Troy LePage, the director of internal audit and enterprise compliance at HAI Group, a captive insurer serving the affordable housing industry, answers some commonly asked questions and provides critical points to consider around incorporating an internal audit function into an overall corporate governance program. He says that by establishing an internal audit function, captive insurers can make every area of their business more effective, efficient, and accurate.

Carol Pierce, senior director with Kroll Bond Rating Agency, delves into corporate governance in the credit rating process and says that governance is an art, not an exact science, and vigilance at staying on top of good governance practices is key to remaining out of the headlines for transgressions.

Independent consultant Dawne Ware reviews the benefits of the independent director on captive boards. She says having an independent director on your board is considered a "best practice" in corporate governance, and the reasons are compelling.

Ben Whitehouse, senior counsel with Butler Snow, LLP, in Nashville, discusses a number of salient points that should be the feature of any captive insurance program, regardless of size. He says sound corporate governance will help keep your captive in good standing with the regulator and can identify problems before they become serious.

Captive Insurance Companies Association President Dan Towle focuses on how his organization is working to meet the challenges of dynamic change in the captive insurance industry. He says many emerging professionals have not had the opportunity to participate in internships, mentorships, and risk management and insurance curricula. This reality is being exacerbated by the accelerating rate of retirements of current professionals, emerging technologies, and operational transformations.
P. Bruce Wright and Saren Goldner of Eversheds Sutherland dig into the details related to the Johnson & Johnson tax court case appeal.
